title: Overall [0–9]
stimulusHtml:
9 points

This question was intended to test a student’s ability to creatively synthesize all the various components (aural, logical, melodic, harmonic and contrapuntal) that have been studied in AP Music Theory into a short composition. The entire soprano line was provided with a given bass line and suggested harmonization for the first one and one-half phrases. The student was asked to continue, in a style characteristic with the given material, the bass line and suggested harmonic analysis through the remaining two and one-half phrases. The question, in addition, tested knowledge of cadences, secondary functions, and modulation.

I. Phrases (8 points: 2 points phrase 2; 3 points each phrases 3 and 4)

  1. Judging each phrase

    Award up to 2 points for the second phrase using the method below.

    Award up to 3 points each for the third and fourth phrases using the method below.

    1. Conceal the harmonies and judge the bass line to be good, fair, or poor against the given melody.

    2. Conceal the bass line and judge the harmonies against the given melody.

      1. If a bass line is good or fair, judge the harmonies to be good to fair or poor.

      2. If a bass line is poor, judge the harmonies to be very good, good to fair, or poor.

    3. Combine the bass line evaluation with that of the harmonies to determine the phrase descriptor.

    4. Award the number of points that corresponds to the phrase descriptor.

  2. Consider the following information when judging each phrase.

    1. The bass should consist of rhythmic values specified in the instructions to the question.

    2. There should be at least two chords per measure. Inversions of the same harmony are acceptable; e.g., I I6 counts as two chords in a measure.

    3. Inversions and seventh chords are acceptable, if used appropriately.

    4. Parallel (consecutive) and beat-to-beat octaves or fifths as well as 8ves or 5ths by contrary motion are considered to be more egregious than the following errors:

      1. Similar motion to a P5 or P8 when the skip is in the upper voice.

      2. Inappropriate or poor treatment of the leading tone.

      3. Unresolved sevenths or incorrectly resolved sevenths.

      4. Excessive or inappropriate leaps (e.g., TT, A2, 7th, 9th or larger).

      5. Implied inappropriate (incorrect) six-four chords.

      6. Repeated notes over a barline.

    5. Inner voices, if notated, should be ignored.

    6. Consider each phrase independently.

    7. Do not judge the connections between phrases.

    8. Do not use fractional points; rely on the phrase descriptors to determine the points to award.

  3. Aesthetic Point (1 point)
    Award 1 point for truly musical responses.
    N.B. A response need not be technically perfect before considering it for the aesthetic point. Therefore, students who earned 6-8 points under Section I may be considered for the aesthetic point.

Scores with Additional Meaning

  • 1 A response that earns a zero using I. 1. and I. 2. above, but has some redeeming qualities.

  • 0 A response that demonstrates an attempt to answer the question, but has no redeeming qualities.

II. Summary of Phrase Scoring

  1. Summary of the Method for Scoring Phrase 2

    Bass Line: good
    Harmonies: good to fair
    Phrase Descriptor: good
    Score: 2

    Bass Line: good
    Harmonies: poor ( = incorrect, inappropriate, or none)
    Phrase Descriptor: fair
    Score: 1

    Bass Line: fair
    Harmonies: good to fair
    Phrase Descriptor: fair
    Score: 1

    Bass Line: fair
    Harmonies: poor ( = incorrect, inappropriate, or none)
    Phrase Descriptor: poor
    Score: 0

    Bass Line: poor or none
    Harmonies: good
    Phrase Descriptor: fair
    Score: 1

    Bass Line: poor or none
    Harmonies: fair
    Phrase Descriptor: poor
    Score: 0

    Bass Line: fair
    Harmonies: poor ( = incorrect, inappropriate, or none)
    Phrase Descriptor: poor
    Score: 0

  2. Summary of the Method for Scoring Phrases 3 and 4

    Bass Line: good
    Harmonies: good to fair
    Phrase Descriptor: good
    Score: 3

    Bass Line: good
    Harmonies: poor ( = incorrect, inappropriate, or none)
    Phrase Descriptor: fair
    Score: 2

    Bass Line: fair
    Harmonies: good to fair
    Phrase Descriptor: fair
    Score: 2

    Bass Line: fair
    Harmonies: poor ( = incorrect, inappropriate, or none)
    Phrase Descriptor: weak
    Score: 1

    Bass Line: poor or none
    Harmonies: very good (i.e., perfect, or nearly perfect)
    Phrase Descriptor: fair
    Score: 2

    Bass Line: poor or none
    Harmonies: good to fair
    Phrase Descriptor: weak
    Score: 1

    Bass Line: poor or none
    Harmonies:     poor ( = incorrect, inappropriate, or none)
    Phrase Descriptor:     very poor
    Score:     0

  3. Judging a phrase’s bass line or harmonies in halves (phrases 3 and 4 only)

    To more easily reach a decision in Section I. 1., you may evaluate the bass line or the harmonies in halves using the guide below.

    First Half of Phrase: Good
    Second Half of Phrase: Fair
    Descriptor of Bass line or Harmonies: Good

    First Half of Phrase: Good
    Second Half of Phrase: Poor
    Descriptor of Bass line or Harmonies: Fair

    First Half of Phrase: Fair
    Second Half of Phrase: Good
    Descriptor of Bass line or Harmonies: Good

    First Half of Phrase: Fair
    Second Half of Phrase: Poor
    Descriptor of Bass line or Harmonies: Poor

    First Half of Phrase: Poor
    Second Half of Phrase: Good
    Descriptor of Bass line or Harmonies: Fair

    First Half of Phrase: Poor
    Second Half of Phrase: Fair
    Descriptor of Bass line or Harmonies: Poor

  4. Judging a phrase consisting only of a good cadence (phrases 3 and 4 only)

    Award 1 point for a phrase that has a poor beginning if three chords at the cadence are good in both bass and harmonies.

    1. The bass should consist of rhythmic values specified in the instructions to the question.

    2. There should be at least two chords per measure. Inversions of the same harmony are acceptable; e.g., I I6 counts as two chords in a measure.

    3. Inversions and seventh chords are acceptable, if used appropriately.

    4. Parallel (consecutive) and beat-to-beat octaves or fifths as well as 8ves or 5ths by contrary motion are considered to be more egregious than the following errors:

      1. Similar motion to a P5 or P8 when the skip is in the upper voice.

      2. Inappropriate or poor treatment of the leading tone.

      3. Unresolved sevenths or incorrectly resolved sevenths.

      4. Excessive or inappropriate leaps (e.g., TT, A2, 7th, 9th or larger).

      5. Implied inappropriate (incorrect) six-four chords.

      6. Repeated notes over a barline.

    5. Inner voices, if notated, should be ignored.

    6. Consider each phrase independently.

    7. Do not judge the connections between phrases.

    8. Do not use fractional points; rely on the phrase descriptors to determine the points to award.

  3. Aesthetic Point (1 point)
    Award 1 point for truly musical responses.
    N.B. A response need not be technically perfect before considering it for the aesthetic point. Therefore, students who earned 6-8 points under Section I may be considered for the aesthetic point.

Scores with Additional Meaning

  • 1 A response that earns a zero using I. 1. and I. 2. above, but has some redeeming qualities.

  • 0 A response that demonstrates an attempt to answer the question, but has no redeeming qualities.

Student response earns 5 of the following points:

I. Phrases (8 points: 2 points phrase 2; 3 points each phrases 3 and 4)

  1. Judging each phrase

    Award up to 2 points for the second phrase using the method below.

    Award up to 3 points each for the third and fourth phrases using the method below.

    1. Conceal the harmonies and judge the bass line to be good, fair, or poor against the given melody.

    2. Conceal the bass line and judge the harmonies against the given melody.

      1. If a bass line is good or fair, judge the harmonies to be good to fair or poor.

      2. If a bass line is poor, judge the harmonies to be very good, good to fair, or poor.

    3. Combine the bass line evaluation with that of the harmonies to determine the phrase descriptor.

    4. Award the number of points that corresponds to the phrase descriptor.

  2. Consider the following information when judging each phrase.

    1. The bass should consist of rhythmic values specified in the instructions to the question.

    2. There should be at least two chords per measure. Inversions of the same harmony are acceptable; e.g., I I6 counts as two chords in a measure.

    3. Inversions and seventh chords are acceptable, if used appropriately.

    4. Parallel (consecutive) and beat-to-beat octaves or fifths as well as 8ves or 5ths by contrary motion are considered to be more egregious than the following errors:

      1. Similar motion to a P5 or P8 when the skip is in the upper voice.

      2. Inappropriate or poor treatment of the leading tone.

      3. Unresolved sevenths or incorrectly resolved sevenths.

      4. Excessive or inappropriate leaps (e.g., TT, A2, 7th, 9th or larger).

      5. Implied inappropriate (incorrect) six-four chords.

      6. Repeated notes over a barline.

    5. Inner voices, if notated, should be ignored.

    6. Consider each phrase independently.

    7. Do not judge the connections between phrases.

    8. Do not use fractional points; rely on the phrase descriptors to determine the points to award.

  3. Aesthetic Point (1 point)
    Award 1 point for truly musical responses.
    N.B. A response need not be technically perfect before considering it for the aesthetic point. Therefore, students who earned 6-8 points under Section I may be considered for the aesthetic point.

  1. Summary of the Method for Scoring Phrase 2

    Bass Line: good
    Harmonies: good to fair
    Phrase Descriptor: good
    Score: 2

    Bass Line: good
    Harmonies: poor ( = incorrect, inappropriate, or none)
    Phrase Descriptor: fair
    Score: 1

    Bass Line: fair
    Harmonies: good to fair
    Phrase Descriptor: fair
    Score: 1

    Bass Line: fair
    Harmonies: poor ( = incorrect, inappropriate, or none)
    Phrase Descriptor: poor
    Score: 0

    Bass Line: poor or none
    Harmonies: good
    Phrase Descriptor: fair
    Score: 1

    Bass Line: poor or none
    Harmonies: fair
    Phrase Descriptor: poor
    Score: 0

    Bass Line: fair
    Harmonies: poor ( = incorrect, inappropriate, or none)
    Phrase Descriptor: poor
    Score: 0

  2. Summary of the Method for Scoring Phrases 3 and 4

    Bass Line: good
    Harmonies: good to fair
    Phrase Descriptor: good
    Score: 3

    Bass Line: good
    Harmonies: poor ( = incorrect, inappropriate, or none)
    Phrase Descriptor: fair
    Score: 2

    Bass Line: fair
    Harmonies: good to fair
    Phrase Descriptor: fair
    Score: 2

    Bass Line: fair
    Harmonies: poor ( = incorrect, inappropriate, or none)
    Phrase Descriptor: weak
    Score: 1

    Bass Line: poor or none
    Harmonies: very good (i.e., perfect, or nearly perfect)
    Phrase Descriptor: fair
    Score: 2

    Bass Line: poor or none
    Harmonies: good to fair
    Phrase Descriptor: weak
    Score: 1

    Bass Line: poor or none
    Harmonies: poor ( = incorrect, inappropriate, or none)
    Phrase Descriptor: very poor
    Score: 0

  3. Judging a phrase’s bass line or harmonies in halves (phrases 3 and 4 only)

    To more easily reach a decision in Section I. 1., you may evaluate the bass line or the harmonies in halves using the guide below.

    First Half of Phrase: Good
    Second Half of Phrase: Fair
    Descriptor of Bass line or Harmonies: Good

    First Half of Phrase: Good
    Second Half of Phrase: Poor
    Descriptor of Bass line or Harmonies: Fair

    First Half of Phrase: Fair
    Second Half of Phrase: Good
    Descriptor of Bass line or Harmonies: Good

    First Half of Phrase: Fair
    Second Half of Phrase: Poor
    Descriptor of Bass line or Harmonies: Poor

    First Half of Phrase: Poor
    Second Half of Phrase: Good
    Descriptor of Bass line or Harmonies: Fair

    First Half of Phrase: Poor
    Second Half of Phrase: Fair
    Descriptor of Bass line or Harmonies: Poor

  4. Judging a phrase consisting only of a good cadence (phrases 3 and 4 only)

    Award 1 point for a phrase that has a poor beginning if three chords at the cadence are good in both bass and harmonies.
